title: What was Amelia Earhart's last message before disappearing? | The World | ABC NEWS
description: The Trump administration has released thousands of files related to renowned aviator Amelia Earhart, who vanished in 1937 during her attempt to become the first woman to circumnavigate the world. The Director of National Intelligence said the release was about "finding and telling the truth", though many experts say the information was already widely available. Laurie Gwen Shapiro - a filmmaker, journalist and author who has spent years researching Amelia Earhart's life - tells The World the release of the documents was "conveniently timed". #ABCTheWorld #ABCAsiaPacific  Subscribe: http://ab.co/1svxLVE  ABC NEWS provides around the clock coverage of news events as they break in Australia and abroad. title: Understanding ADHD symptoms such as RSD, hyper-focus, task paralysis | ABC NEWS
description: Attention-Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder, or ADHD diagnoses are on the rise in Australia.   Experts say the condition isn't necessarily becoming more common, but increasing awareness of the disorder is leading more neurodiverse people to seek out answers.  This story, unpacking the sometimes "invisible symptoms" of ADHD, has been produced for the ABC's 2025 coverage of International Day of People with Disability. Reporter Gemma Ferguson worked alongside artist Mark du Potiers for ABC News Northern Territory. title: IN FULL: US House of Representatives vote to release more Epstein files | ABC NEWS
description: The US House of Representatives have voted in favour of a measure to force the release of more files related to the late convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein. All in all, 427 voted for the bill, and a single Republican voted against.  The chamber broke out into cheers and applause when the official result was announced. title: Crown VS State: how Tonga's royal past shaped its democratic future | ABC News
description: It's been 15 years since Tonga introduced democratic reforms, but tensions are still flaring between the crown and state. With the elections just around the corner, reporter Marian Kupu takes a closer look at the Kingdom's democracy movement. title: Britain's MI5 issues security alert over Chinese spy threat | ABC NEWS
description: Britain's MI5 security service has warned lawmakers, economist and thinktank workers about attempts by Chinese agents to collect sensitive information and influence activity. MI5 staff identified two LinkedIn profiles, which it says are used on behalf of the Chinese Ministry of State Security. UK Security Minister Dan Jarvis says the British government would not tolerate threats posed by state actors. title: The coloured sand that sparked an asbestos scare | ABC News Daily podcast
description: Asbestos is highly carcinogenic, is banned and can’t be imported in Australia.    But in the last week it’s been found in various children’s coloured sand products from China, causing a major alarm across the community.    The discovery has led to the closure of dozens of schools and products have been recalled from stores including Kmart, Target and Officeworks.   Today, Associate Professor Anthony Linton from the Asbestos and Dust Diseases Research Institute on the health risks the sand poses and why every state is dealing with it differently.   Featured:    Anthony Linton, academic and research director at the Asbestos and Dust Diseases Research Institute

title: NSW to strengthen laws to combat displays of Nazi ideology | ABC NEWS
description: The NSW parliament will give greater powers to police and courts to combat displays of Nazi ideology. About 60 neo-Nazis held a rally outside NSW parliament on November 8, prompting the government to act. The new laws will ban the use of Nazi chants and slogans. title: Trump insists Saudi crown prince knew nothing about Khashoggi killing | ABC NEWS
description: Trump welcomed the Saudi crown prince to the White House and denied Prince Mohammed bin Salman's involvement in the killing of journalist Jamal Khashoggi. This contradicts US intelligence, which suggests that Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman approved the killing. During his visit to Washington, the crown prince pledged to boost his country's investment in the US to $US1 trillion ($1.5 trillion). title: Epstein files release now sits with Trump after agreement in the House, Senate | ABC NEWS
description: A bill to force the release of the "Epstein files" has passed the US Congress. Just one Republican voted against it, though others said they feared innocent people could be caught up in the release of the files. Donald Trump, who initially opposed the bill, has said he will sign the bill if it reaches his desk. The files would then need to be released within 30 days. title: Former colleague of Jamal Khashoggi calls Trump's comments 'reprehensible' | ABC NEWS
description: US President Donald Trump welcomed Saudi Arabia's leader to the White House and dismissed questions about the 2018 murder of journalist Jamal Khashoggi. The crown prince denied ordering the operation but acknowledged responsibility as the kingdom's de facto ruler. Jason Rezaian, a former colleague of Khashoggi at The Washington Post, says that Khashoggi's writing and journalism called for modernisation and democratisation in Saudi Arabia and other Persian Gulf countries.
